title: 5 Tips to Improve Immunity After Second COVID Booster
author: Peter Urban
description: From timing your second booster shot to exercising after, you can help your body produce more antibodies. Learn how to improve your immune response.
cleaned_text: Staying Fit If you are 50 or older, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) now [recommends a second COVID-19 booster](/health/conditions-treatments/info-2022/second-covid-booster-shot.html) shot of either the Pfizer-BioNTech or the Moderna vaccine at least four months after getting the first booster. As Yale New Haven Health Chief Clinical Officer Thomas Balcezak explained, the vaccines have been proved to reduce the risk of hospitalization and death from [COVID-19](/health/conditions-treatments/info-2020/coronavirus-facts.html), but the level of protection does start to wane. A [recent CDC analysis](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/71/wr/mm7107e2.htm?s_cid=mm7107e2_w) found that after four months, the effectiveness of a booster shot in preventing hospitalizations declined from 91 to 78 percent. "It's really important, I think, for folks over the age of 50, particularly those who have [comorbid conditions](/health/conditions-treatments/info-2021/covid-underlying-conditions/?s_cid=mm7107e2_w.html) like diabetes or underlying lung disease, to go ahead and seek and get that booster now," Balcezak said during a recent press conference streamed on Facebook and Zoom. Be well rested Studies have shown that sleep matters when it comes to enhancing your response to vaccines. "Getting sufficient [high-quality sleep](/health/healthy-living/info-2021/sleep-patterns.html) on a regular basis strengthens your body's immune system and optimizes your response to a vaccine," American Academy of Sleep Medicine President Kannan Ramar, M.D., said in a statement. A 2020 [study](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12529-020-09879-4) in the International Journal of Behavioral Medicine found that the [flu vaccine](/health/conditions-treatments/info-2022/older-adults-high-dose-flu-shot.html) appears to be more effective in people who get adequate sleep for the two nights prior to receiving the shot. Similar results have been found in other studies on vaccines for hepatitis A and hepatitis B, which showed lower antibody responses among individuals who got less sleep. "Studies have shown that normal sleep after vaccination strengthens the immune response against an invading antigen and this immunity-boosting effect of sleep is clinically significant," Khurshid A.
